Highly efficient Mn2O3 catalysts derived from Mn-MOFs for toluene oxidation: The influence of MOFs precursors Xiaodong Zhang a * Xutian Lv a Fukun Bi a Guang Lu c Yuxin Wang b * a School of Environment and Architecture, University of Shanghai for Science and Technology, Shanghai 200093, China School of Environment and Architecture University of Shanghai for Science and Technology Shanghai 200093 China School of Environment and Architecture, University of Shanghai for Science and Technology, Shanghai 200093, China b Institute of Applied Biotechnology, Taizhou Vocation & Technical College, Taizhou Zhejiang 318000, China Institute of Applied Biotechnology Taizhou Vocation & Technical College Taizhou Zhejiang 318000 China Institute of Applied Biotechnology, Taizhou Vocation & Technical College, Taizhou Zhejiang 318000, China c College of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Environmental Engineering, Liaoning Shihua University, Fushun, Liaoning, 113001, China College of Chemistry Chemical Engineering and Environmental Engineering Liaoning Shihua University Fushun Liaoning 113001 China College of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Environmental Engineering, Liaoning Shihua University, Fushun, Liaoning, 113001, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The effect of Mn-MOFs precursors (Mn-MIL-100, Mn-MOF-74 and Mn-BTC) on the performance of Mn2O3 catalysts pretreated with different atmosphere (Ar, O2 and O2 after Ar treatment) for toluene oxidation is investigated in this work, respectively. The characteristics of the catalysts are investigated by using scanning electron microscope (SEM), the X-ray diffraction (XRD), Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR). It is observed that Mn-MIL-100 pretreated with Ar and then with O2 (Mn-100-Ar-O) shows better catalytic activity for toluene oxidation than Mn-MIL-100 pretreated with single Ar or O2. Furthermore, MOFs precursors have strongly influence on the structure and performance of Mn2O3 catalysts. The order of catalytic activity is as follows: Mn-100-Ar-O > Mn-BTC-Ar-O > Mn-74-Ar-O. In addition, Mn-100-Ar-O exhibits high stability, circulation performance and water resistance. The catalytic performance of Mn-100-Ar-O is obviously improved with the better reduction at low-temperature and the increase of surface molar ratio of Mn3+/Mn4+ and Oads/Olatt. Keywords Toluene oxidation MOFs Mn2O3 Precursors Atmosphere 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are rich in variety, such as benzene, acetone, acetic acid and toluene. VOCs are hazardous environmental pollutants because they are precursors of ozone and smog [1–3]. Therefore, it is an eager task to control the emissions of VOCs. So far, control VOCs techniques include membrane separation, plasma process, adsorption, wet scrubbing, catalytic oxidation for removing toluene [4–8]. Catalytic oxidation is considered to be one of the most beneficial ways with no secondary pollution products and in relatively mild methods for various pollutants [9–13]. To try to find an active catalyst with low cost and high activity for toluene oxidation is attracting much research. Transition metal oxides, noble metal and zeolite have been applied as catalysts for oxidation of VOCs. Although noble metal catalysts show excellent catalytic oxidation activities for VOCs at low temperatures, expensive price and low reserve limit their widely practical applications. Compared with noble metal catalysts, transition metal oxides show excellent performance in low cost and higher thermal stability, such as chromium oxide, cobalt oxides, and manganese oxide [14–18]. However, to develop a high activity catalyst at low temperature still is a challenge for catalytic oxidation of VOCs. In recent years, various preparation methods of manganese oxides, such as sol-gel method, precipitation method and hydrothermal method, have been studied extensively. [19–21]. Now, a new method for synthesizing metal oxides has emerged, which is the decomposition of metal organic frameworks (MOFs) [22–25]. MOFs are a kind of coordination polymer and have many advantages of high specific surface area, high energy storage and adjustable aperture. The applications of MOFs cover a wide range of field, such as photocatalysis [26–31], adsorption [32–38] and catalysis [39–43]. Furthermore, the MIL-100 series is a typical example for metal–organic frameworks with outstanding chemical stability. MIL-100 can be composed of [M(III)(μ3-O)(OH)(H2O)2(BTC)2] (BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) units and be prepared with metal ions Fe3+, Cr3+, Al3+, V3+, Sc3+ and Mn3+ [44–48]. Besides the desirable characteristics on above, the chemical characteristics of these materials are mainly reflected in the coordination chemistry of the trimeric building units. The octahedral coordination geometry is accomplished by the cations, μ3-oxide ion, hydroxide ion, weakly bound water molecule and six carboxylate groups. In this way, coordinated unsaturated sites can be created within the framework. These can be used for coordination by other ligands or catalytic conversion sites [49,50]. In addition, a variety of divalent ions are comprised in M2DOBDC (MOF-74). A large number of open metal sites in one-dimensional cylindrical pores with a diameter of 1.1 nm in MOF-74. Each metal ion is surrounded by pentacoordinated peroxygen vesicle composed of weak field carboxylate and phenate which promotes high spin electron configuration, and providing more accessible redox pairs so they are beneficial to the study of oxidation reaction [51,52]. Moreover, Mn2+ ions and oxygen-containing trimesic acid linkers form Mn-based organic compounds (denoted as Mn-BTC) [53]. The metal cluster of the MOFs can be transformed for metal nanoparticles or metal oxide nanoparticles after high temperature calcination, and the organic frameworks form porous carbon material. The mentioned nanocomposite can show that the metal oxidation nanoparticles are coated with porous carbon, metal active sites are highly dispersed and are difficult to agglomeration [54–57]. Furtherly, our studies have found that porous Mn2O3 derived from Mn-MIL-100 displayed high capacity, good cycling stability and excellent catalytic activity for CO oxidation [58]. Sun et al. reported MnOx with various preparation methods (co-precipitation, thermal decomposition and pyrolysis of MOFs) for toluene oxidation, and found that MnOx obtained from MOFs have excellent catalytic activity for toluene oxidation, which is ascribed to the existence of surface defects and the high capacity for adsorbing oxygen [59]. Zhao et al. studied the different sizes of hollow Co3O4 derived from ZIF-67 having an effect on toluene oxidation [60]. It is found that 400 nm Co3O4 has most Co3+ concentration on the surface of catalysts. However, so far, there have been few studies on the comparative research of manganese oxides derived from various different MOFs precursors. The purpose of this work is to investigate the influence of Mn-MOFs precursors for the catalytic performance of toluene oxidation over Mn2O3 catalysts. Here, a series of Mn2O3 derived from different Mn-MOFs precursors (Mn-MIL-100, Mn-MOF-74 and Mn-BTC) are synthesized. Mn2O3 catalysts are used to investigate the effect of the pretreatment atmosphere and precursors for structure of catalyst and catalytic toluene performance. 2 Experiment section 2.1 Catalyst preparation The purity of all reactants and solvents are analytical level and are not further purified. Three different Mn-MOFs precursors are prepared. For MIL-100 [48], 0.50 g Mn(NO3)2·4H2O and 0.39 g C6H3(COOH)3 are dissolved by 18 ml CH3OH with stirring. The reaction mixture is stirred until completely dissolved at normal temperature, and then placed in a 150 ml Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave at 120 °C for 2 h. After naturally cooling to room temperature in an autoclave, the precipitate is washed three times with ethanol, and finally dried at 80 °C oven. For Mn-MOFs-74 [61], 0.67 g C8H6O6 are dissolved in a 30 ml mixture of DMF-ethanol-water with a volume ratio of 15:1:1 (v/v/v) and add 0.22 g MnCl2·4H2O. The reaction solution is then transferred into a 150 ml Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The mixtures are kept inside the furnace at 135 °C for 2 h and then naturally cool to room temperature. Finally, dark orange crystalline is washed several times with DMF and dried in an 80 °C oven to obtain Mn-MOFs-74. For Mn-BTC [49], Solution A: 0.49 g Mn(CH3COO)·4H2O and 0.3 g PVP are dissolved in a 10 ml mixture of ethanol-water with 1:1 (v/v) under stirring to give a transparent solution. Solution B: 0.09 g trimesic acid is also dissolved in a 10 ml mixture of ethanol-water with 1:1 (v/v) under stirring to give a transparent solution. Solution B is added to the solution A at room temperature with stirring. After 30 min, the mixed solution is transferred into Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and reacted at room temperature for 24 h. The white product is centrifuged after cooling to room temperature, washed with ethanol, and finally dried in 80 °C oven. Then, the MIL-100 is calcined at 700 °C Ar for 2 h with the heating rate of 5 °C/min to obtain Mn-100-Ar, and the pyrolysis of MIL-100 at 700 °C O2 for 2 h to get Mn-100-O. And the sample of MIL-100 is first treated at 700 °C Ar for 2 h and then treated at 700 °C O2 for 2 h, which is named as Mn-100-Ar-O. In addition, the obtained other two Mn-MOFs precursors are first calcined at 700 °C Ar for 2 h and then treated at 700 °C O2 for 2 h to finally form Mn-74-Ar-O and Mn-BTC-Ar-O, respectively. 2.2 Catalysts characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns with the crystal structures of samples prepared in this work are examined by a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer with monochromatic detector and equipped with Cu Kα radiation of wavelength 0.154 nm. And the scan angle is 10-80°, the scan rate is 5°/min, the operating current is 40 mA and the voltage is 40 kV. N2 adsorption-desorption curve of the catalysts prepared are measured by Quantachrome autosorb-iQ-2MP apparatus of Quantachrome Company. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller method (BET) and Non Local Density Functional Theory (NLDFT) of desorption branch were utilized to calculate specific surface areas and pore diameter, respectively. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images is measured by a Tescan (VEGA-3-SBH) instrument. The instrument's accelerating voltage is 10 KV. And the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images are measured by Tecnai G2 F20 instrument from FEI company, USA. The instrument's accelerating voltage is 200 KV. The reduction properties of the samples are carried out by the temperature programmed reduction (TPR) using ChemBET TPR / TPD diluted with Ar gas under 10 vol % H2 stream. The samples (50 mg) are exposed to a stream of H2/Ar mixture. The temperature is raised from room temperature to 850 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is performed by THERMO ESCALAB 250XZ. The binding energies (Eb) are calibrated internally by the carbon deposit C1 s binding energy at 284.6 eV. 2.3 Catalytic testing The catalytic oxidation of toluene is carried out in a fixed bed flow reactor at atmospheric pressure. Toluene gas is bubbled with argon gas to carry out catalytic oxidation with a toluene concentration of 1000 ppm, and 0.1 g (20–40 mesh) of catalyst powder is packed in a quartz tube reactor (outer diameter 6 mm). Catalytic activity is measured at a total flow rate of 50 ml/min and controlled by an independent thermal mass flow controller. The data reported at the reaction temperature is the average value of at least three measurements. Both inlet and outlet gases were analyzed on-line using GC2060 gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a flame ionization detector. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 The effect of treatment atmosphere In our previous work, the catalyst of the pretreatment temperature with 700 °C is beneficial to enhance catalytic activity [43]. Moreover, in order to determine the treatment atmosphere, Mn-100-Ar, Mn-100-O and Mn-100-Ar-O have been prepared via pyrolysis of Mn-MIL-100 in Ar, O2 and O2 after Ar treatment atmospheres, respectively. As shown in Fig. 1 , Mn-100-Ar-O exhibits excellent catalytic activity for toluene oxidation, which is indicated the atmosphere influences the toluene catalytic performance of Mn2O3 catalyst. The final conversion temperature of Mn-100-Ar-O is 270 °C. Further, a series of characterizations of Mn-100-Ar, Mn-100-O and Mn-100-Ar-O are investigated. The XRD patterns of Mn-100-Ar, Mn-100-O and Mn-100-Ar-O are shown in Fig. 2 . The XRD peaks for all catalysts in the 2θ range of 20-70° display similar patterns and can be well corresponded to the standard Mn2O3 sample (JCPDS41-1442). The characteristic diffraction peaks of Mn2O3 at 23.0°, 32.8°, 38.1°, 45.2°, 49.2°, 53.3°, 55.0°, 60.6°, 64.1°, 65.8° and 67.4° are correspond to (211), (222), (400), (332), (431), (521), (440), (611), (541), (622) and (631) crystal faces, respectively. Moreover, it is calculated the crystallite size by the Scherrer’s formula, the crystallite size of Mn-100-Ar, Mn-100-O and Mn-100-Ar-O are 30.6 nm, 31.4 nm and 28.7 nm, respectively. Mn-100-Ar-O shows the smallest crystallite size. The N2 absorption-desorption isotherms and pore-size distributions of Mn-100-Ar, Mn-100-O and Mn-100-Ar-O are performed in Fig. S1. It can be discovered that all three catalysts display type IV isotherms with H3 hysteresis loops, which is demonstrated that the existence of mesopores on three catalysts. However, the micropores structure can also be observed in the pore size distribution curves of Mn-100-Ar. As summarized in Table S1, Mn-100-Ar shows larger surface area (141.5 m2/g), which may be ascribed to the generation of carbon framework after calcination in the insufficient oxygen atmosphere. Although Mn-100-Ar-O possess the smaller surface area (7.7 m2/g), the Mn-100-Ar-O shows better catalytic performance for toluene oxidation. This result is matched to our previous report, the specific surface area of Mn2O3-700 (Mn-MIL-100 obtained by calcined at 700 °C) displays smaller, but exhibits better catalytic performance [43]. Mn-100-Ar-O shows excellent catalytic activity, which may be ascribed to the small crystallite size and the unique structure. So the O2 after Ar treatment atmospheres is chosen as pretreatment atmosphere in this work. 3.2 Characterization of Mn2O3 catalysts In order to investigate the structure of Mn-MOFs, a series of characterizations of Mn-MOFs are carried out. The X-ray diffraction peaks of MIL-100, Mn-MOF-74 and Mn-BTC are generated in Fig. S2. As previous reports [47–49], MIL-100, Mn-MOF-74 and Mn-BTC are successfully synthesized. In addition, the N2 absorption-desorption isotherms and pore-size distributions of MIL-100, Mn-MOF-74 and Mn-BTC are performed in Fig. S3. The BET results of MIL-100, Mn-MOF-74 and Mn-BTC are recorded in Table S2. It can be clearly found that three Mn-MOFs precursors show large specific surface area and microporous structure. The XRD peaks of prepared MnOx with different precursors are illustrated in Fig. 3 . All diffraction peaks demonstrated in the patterns corresponded to characteristic of the standard Mn2O3 (JCPDS41-1442). The XRD signal position of the three samples has been observed no significant difference. The signal intensity of Mn-100-Ar-O sample shows the weakest peaks. It is discovered that the crystallite size of Mn-100-Ar-O shows the smallest crystallite size (28.7 nm). The XRD results reveal that the precursors have a significant effect on crystal structure of Mn2O3 sample. The morphology structure of Mn-100-Ar-O, Mn-74-Ar-O and Mn-BTC-Ar-O are investigated by scanning electron microscope (SEM) technique, and the pictures are shown in Fig. 4 . After the calcination of Mn-MOFs, the morphology of three samples make changes. Mn-100-Ar-O exhibits the irregular structure, Mn-74-Ar-O also displays an irregular morphology and appears a certain degree of aggregation, Mn-BTC-Ar-O shows rod morphology. Furthermore, the average diameter range of Mn-100-Ar-O is from 0.5 um to 1 um. And the average diameter of Mn-74-Ar-O and Mn-BTC-Ar-O (Fig. 4c and d) are over 2 um. The phenomenon can be explained that three catalysts are derived from different Mn-MOFs precursors. Moreover, the Mn-100-Ar-O sample is further characterized by TEM (Fig. 4e). The obtained Mn-100-Ar-O is polycrystal. It is noted that lattice spacing of manganese oxide in HRTEM (Fig. 4f) over Mn-100-Ar-O sample, and the lattice fringe at 4.77 Å is consistent with the (211) crystal face of Mn2O3. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 5 . As shown in Fig. 5A, all the catalysts exhibit typical features of type IV isotherms with an H3 hysteresis loop. The behavior corresponds to the existence of mesoporous structures on the catalysts. The specific surface area of Mn-100-Ar-O, Mn-74-Ar-O and Mn-BTC-Ar-O are 7.7 m2/g, 5.4 m2/g and 7.9 m2/g, respectively. No obvious changes are found in the specific surface area and the distribution of pore sizes (Table 1 ). This result illustrates that the specific surface area and the dispersion of pore sizes of the catalysts have no important effect on catalytic performance of the oxidation for toluene. It is found that micropores disappeared after heat process, which may be ascribed to the collapse of the framework during the pyrolysis of the Mn-MOFs. In general, it is considered that the larger pore size is contributed to reduce migrate resistance and improve catalytic activity. The relative reducibility of the catalysts is investigated by H2-TPR experiments. As shown in Fig. 6 , the reduction peaks of three samples behave in the following two procedures. The former reduction peaks is attributed to the transformation of Mn2O3 to Mn3O4, and the later reduction peaks is ascribed to the transformation of Mn3O4 to MnO [62,63]. Mn-74-Ar-O shows two dispersion reduction peaks at 420 °C and 487 °C, and Mn-BTC-Ar-O exhibits two reduction peaks at 408 °C and 474 °C. Further, Mn-100-Ar-O displays two peaks at 379 °C and 434 °C, two reduction process of Mn-100-Ar-O both show at lower temperature than Mn-74-Ar-O and Mn-BTC-Ar-O. In addition, the reducibility of the samples usually is closely associated to its catalytic property, and the lower reduction temperature of sample usually shows higher catalytic performance. The reduction ability of the samples is reduced in the order of Mn-100-Ar-O > Mn-BTC-Ar-O > Mn-74-Ar-O, which demonstrates that Mn-100-Ar-O sample has stronger reducibility at low-temperature and more oxygen species. The H2-TPR results demonstrate that Mn-MOFs precursors have influences to the reducibility of the catalysts at low temperature. To obtain further the information about elemental chemical states and surface oxygen species, Co 2p and O 1s XPS spectra of the samples were shown in Fig. 6. The information of surface oxygen species and surface elemental chemical states of the catalysts have been observed by XPS. Fig. 7 illustrates the Mn 2p and O 1s XPS spectra of Mn2O3 samples. As shown in Fig. 7, two peaks situated at 641.6 eV and 653.3 eV indicates the existence of Mn 2p3/2 and Mn 2p1/2 signals, respectively [64]. There are asymmetrical signal of two peaks for the Mn2O3 samples. The former peak (Mn 2p3/2) can be curve fitted into two components, characteristic of Mn3+ (641.4 eV) and Mn4+ (643.0 eV) [65]. And the XPS results of the surface molar ratios of Mn3+/Mn4+ is generalized in Table 1. Apparently, the Mn-MOFs precursors have a significant effect on the surface Mn3+/Mn4+ ions ratio of the samples. Among the three Mn2O3 samples derived from Mn-MOFs precursors, Mn-100-Ar-O shows the highest surface molar ratio of Mn3+/Mn4+ (1.11), and the lowest surface molar ratio of Mn3+/Mn4+ (1.02) is attained on Mn-74-Ar-O sample. The increase of surface Mn3+ content can enhance the number of oxygen cavities [66], which demonstrates that a great amount of oxygen vacancies present in the surface of Mn-100-Ar-O catalyst. The asymmetrical O 1s XPS signal can separate two elements are shown in Fig. 7. The former peak at BE =529.4 eV is assigned to surface lattice oxygen (Olatt) species, and the later one at BE =531.3 eV corresponds to the surface adsorbed oxygen (Oads) species [67,68]. The related Oads /Olatt molar ratio results are generalized in Table 1. The surface molar ratio of Oads /Olatt decreased in the order of Mn-100-Ar-O (0.63)> Mn-BTC-Ar-O (0.54)> Mn-74-Ar-O (0.49), which is consistent with the surface molar ratio of Mn3+/Mn4+ [69]. With the increase of surface Mn3+ and Oads contents, Mn2O3 catalysts exhibite better catalytic performance. 3.3 Catalytic performance of catalysts The activity of Mn2O3 sample for toluene oxidation is investigated and shown in Fig. 8 (A), and the catalytic performance is tested at the reaction conditions of toluene concentration = 1000 ppm and 30% O2, toluene conversion rises with the increase of reaction temperature. Notably, toluene is entirely transferred to CO2 and H2O over the catalysts. T10, T50 and T90 (the reaction temperatures are relevant to the toluene conversions of 10%, 50% and 90%) are used to contrast the catalytic performance of the catalysts. It is clearly demonstrated that Mn-100-Ar-O shows better catalytic performance than Mn-BTC-Ar-O and Mn-74-Ar-O. From observing the variety of complete toluene conversion temperature, the catalytic activities are ranked as follows: Mn-100-Ar-O > Mn-BTC-Ar-O > Mn-74-Ar-O. The phenomenon is mainly related to the distribution of the surface oxygen species on the catalysts derived from different Mn-MOFs precursors. For kinetic studies, the combustion oxidation of toluene follows the first order kinetics. There is a mechanism of extra oxygen, and toluene concentration and oxygen concentration are closely related to it: (1) r = -kc = [-Aexp (-Ea/RT)]c where r, k, A, and Ea refer to reaction rate (μmol/(g·s)), rate constant (s−1), pre-exponential factor, and apparent activation energy (kJ/mol), respectively. According to the formula, the Arrhenius diagram can be applied to the calculation of activation energy (Ea) at the conversion of <20%, which is not affected by phase changes or material migration. As shown in Fig. 8(B), the Ea values decrease as follows: Mn-74-Ar-O (163.7 kJ/mol) > Mn-BTC-Ar-O (102.6 kJ/mol) > Mn-100-Ar-O (68.9 kJ/mol). The Mn-100-Ar-O has the lowest Ea value, which shows the best catalytic performance for toluene oxidation. The cyclic catalytic test is carried out 6 times. It is observed that the catalyst remained highly catalytically active during the second to sixth runs in Fig. 9 . The six times final conversion temperature of Mn-100-Ar-O catalysts is approximately 270 °C. As shown in Scheme 1 , the catalysts are prepared by pyrolysis of the Mn-MOFs precursors. After Mn-MOFs are treated at Ar atmosphere, a part of organic skeleton of the catalysts collapse, and others are still considered for skeleton structures. MnOx nanocrystals can be produced from Mn-O clusters after metal organic frameworks (Mn-MIL-100, Mn-MOF-74 and Mn-BTC) treated in Ar atmosphere, and mentioned generated nanocrystals can be further embedded in interconnected porous carbon skeleton materials derived from carbonization of metal organic frameworks. Therefore, the materials have the structure that metal oxide are wrapped with carbon skeleton. With the release of gas molecules (such as CO2, H2O), the elastic porous carbon matrix can be easily obtained by carbonization process. Porous carbon matrix can effectively uniform distribution MnOx nanocrystal [70–77]. And MnOx can be completely oxidized in O2 atmosphere and effectively remove residual carbon frameworks. The morphology of the samples have changed, which may be attributed to the carbon skeleton structure complete collapse during calcination at oxygen atmosphere. Furthermore, the octahedral, spherality and rod-like structures with the self-assembly of metal ions or metal clusters and organic ligands are decomposed due to the absence of the carbon skeleton after calcination. Different particle sizes, structures and morphologies of Mn2O3 are generated, which may be ascribed to the three Mn-MOFs precursors form different carbon framework structures, and the crystal growth of metal oxides are inconsistent during calcination process. A detailed study on the formation process of special structure with Mn2O3 needs to be carried out in the future. It is worth noting that Mn-100-Ar-O catalyst has a small BET surface area (7.7 m2/g). The result means that the BET surface area is not a decisive factor in the catalytic oxidation for toluene. And the H2-TPR results shows that the Mn-100-Ar-O catalyst has a good low temperature reduction ability, more oxygen vacancies and better oxygen mobility [64]. Some articles have also reported that lower temperature reductive and oxygen vacancies are contributed to increasing catalytic activity [64,78]. Therefore, the activity of the Mn-100-Ar-O catalyst is mainly related to its better low-temperature reducibility and more oxygen cavities. In addition, XPS results shows that more Mn3+ and surface adsorbed oxygen species on the surface of Mn-100-Ar-O catalyst, and the related research of results Mn3+ can increase the oxygen vacancies of the catalyst and increase the activity of the catalyst [79]. Furtherly, the Mn-100-Ar-O catalyst has the highest ratio of Oads/Olatt compared to the catalysts Mn-74-Ar-O and Mn-BTC-Ar-O. Previous studies have shown that abundant surface-adsorbed oxygen species can provide more surface oxygen vacancies [69]. More importantly, the surface oxygen vacancies are more easily stripped at the low temperature region, which is contributed to improve the reducing power and catalytic oxidation performance of the catalyst [69]. Therefore, surface active oxygen species play a significant impact on the catalytic oxidation reaction, and this result is corresponded to some previous results [71,80]. The good catalytic performance of the best sample prepared in this paper is mainly related to the active oxygen species on the surface, low-temperature reducing ability and oxygen vacancies of the catalyst. These characteristics allow the reactants to adsorb on the surface of the catalyst, thereby enhancing the catalytic oxidation for toluene. These demonstrate that the catalytic activity and low temperature reductive properties of Mn2O3 catalysts will be affected the difference of Mn-MOFs precursors. 3.4 Effect of water vapor The water resistance of catalyst is significant in practical application. To explore the influence of water vapor on catalytic performance of the best-performing used Mn-100-Ar-O catalyst is investigated. Fig. 10 displays the catalytic performance of Mn-100-Ar-O with the absence and presence of 1.0 vol% water vapor for toluene oxidation. Compared with toluene oxidation performance of absence of water, a little influence of water vapor is seen over Mn-100-Ar-O for toluene oxidation, the catalytic toluene performance of catalyst with water has decreased. The deactivation of the catalyst may be ascribed to that some active sites are occupied by moisture compete with reactants and thus the reaction rate reduce. In addition, the XRD peaks (Fig. 11 ) of the used catalyst is distinct from the fresh one. The XRD curve of used Mn-100-Ar-O catalyst with water is observed a small arouse peak near 30°, which may be attributed to the introduction of water makes difference to the crystalline state of the catalyst, resulting the catalytic performance of Mn-100-Ar-O has decreased. 4 Conclusions A number of Mn2O3 samples with different precursors through pyrolysis of Mn-MOFs, and the pretreatment atmosphere and Mn-MOFs precursors have impact on the catalytic activity is investigated for toluene oxidation reaction. It is noted that Mn-MOFs-100 treated in O2 after Ar treatment atmosphere (Mn-100-Ar-O) shows the best catalytic performance. Further, manganese oxide samples derived from different precursors display different catalytic activities for toluene oxidation. Among Mn2O3 catalysts derived from three Mn-MOFs precursors, Mn-100-Ar-O exhibits superior catalytic activity, which is ascribed to the higher molar ratio of Mn3+/Mn4+ on the catalyst surface, a large number of surface adsorbed oxygen and oxygen species. These conclusions offer a feasible idea to the preparation of highly efficient catalyst for toluene oxidation. coredata.dc:description: The effect of Mn-MOFs precursors (Mn-MIL-100, Mn-MOF-74 and Mn-BTC) on the performance of Mn2O3 catalysts pretreated with different atmosphere (Ar, O2 and O2 after Ar treatment) for toluene oxidation is investigated in this work, respectively. The characteristics of the catalysts are investigated by using scanning electron microscope (SEM), the X-ray diffraction (XRD), Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR). It is observed that Mn-MIL-100 pretreated with Ar and then with O2 (Mn-100-Ar-O) shows better catalytic activity for toluene oxidation than Mn-MIL-100 pretreated with single Ar or O2. Furthermore, MOFs precursors have strongly influence on the structure and performance of Mn2O3 catalysts. The order of catalytic activity is as follows: Mn-100-Ar-O > Mn-BTC-Ar-O > Mn-74-Ar-O. In addition, Mn-100-Ar-O exhibits high stability, circulation performance and water resistance. The catalytic performance of Mn-100-Ar-O is obviously improved with the better reduction at low-temperature and the increase of surface molar ratio of Mn3+/Mn4+ and Oads/Olatt.
coredata.dc:title: Highly efficient Mn2O3 catalysts derived from Mn-MOFs for toluene oxidation: The influence of MOFs precursors
